item.title: ğŸ’» Code, Creativity, and Campus Life â€” My Midâ€‘May Highlights âœ¨

The past seven days felt like one long sprint peppered with ahaâ€‘moments.

ğŸ¨ SFML Geometry Comes Alive

I finally wired up my hierarchy of geometric shapes in SFMLâ€”think circles morphing into triangles, all with virtual inheritance purring under the hood. Seeing the scene run at 60â€¯FPS was the chefâ€™s kiss.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ C++â€¯Vect & Matrix â€” Defense Mode On

Next up: polishing slides for the big Technology Programming lab defense. Iâ€™ve been dissecting every constructor, pointer, and overloaded operator so I can field any curveball.

Miniâ€‘win: rewrote all console outputs to Russian and renamed every variable to something readable. Feels good!

ğŸ§© Scholarship Game Brainstorm

Between compile runs, I sketched mechanics for an interactive scholarship workshop: card decks for types of aid, improv scenes about budgeting, and a scoreboard to keep firstâ€‘years engaged.

ğŸŒ± Sanity Breaks

  • Walks around the MCC loop to clear my head.
  • Evening stretch sessions so my shoulders forgive the laptop hunch.
  • A strict â€œlightsâ€‘outâ€‘byâ€‘midnightâ€ ruleâ€”honestly the best debugging tool.

âœ” Focused Sprints

Iâ€™m timing study blocks with a 45â€¯min / 10â€¯min rhythm. Keeps fatigue away and IDE tabs under control.

âœ” Snack Stack

  • ĞÑ€ĞµÑ…Ğ¸ for quick brain fuel.
  • Ğ“Ñ€ĞµÑ‡ĞºĞ° + veggies = slow carbs that last through a coding marathon.
  • Limiting coffee to 2 cupsâ€”after that itâ€™s herbal tea or bust.

âœ” Move It, Keep It Fun

Short MCC rides double as sightseeing and microâ€‘workouts (hello, standing carriages!). Fresh air resets my focus better than any toâ€‘do app.

ğŸ”„ Your Turn

Whatâ€™s the most satisfying project milestone you hit this week? Drop a commentâ€”letâ€™s swap wins! ğŸ‰

item.title: ğŸŒ¿ Balance Between Study, Activity, and Inner Calm
item.description:
Table of Contents
  • ğŸŒ Activity â€” A Way of Life
  • ğŸ˜´ How to Set a Good Sleep Routine
  • ğŸ“š Study: How to Study Smarter, Not Longer
  • ğŸ” Comments on Techniques
  • ğŸŒ³ Beautiful and Hidden Parks in Moscow
    • ğŸŒ² Lianozovsky Park
    • ğŸŒ³ Kuskovo Forest Park
    • ğŸŒ¿ Timiryazevsky Forest
    • ğŸƒ Bitsevsky Forest
  • ğŸ’¬ Conclusion

ğŸŒ Activity â€” A Way of Life

I try not to sit still every day: morning walks, trips around the Moscow Central Circle (already my favorite habit!), short routes through cozy alleys, or sudden stops in parks with a book. It not only gives me a boost of energy but also inspires me.

I notice how regular walks help me not only physically but mentally. My brain â€œair-dries,â€ new ideas come, and even a tired mind seems to come alive.

ğŸ˜´ How to Set a Good Sleep Routine

Hereâ€™s what really helps me get enough sleep and not lose energy:

  • â° Double alarm: one for waking up and one for going to sleep
  • ğŸ“µ Screen detox one hour before sleep (replace it with a book or notebook)
  • ğŸ§˜â€â™€ï¸ The “3 Blocks” technique:
    1. 60 minutes before bed â€” soft light, no screens
    2. 30 minutes before â€” breathing exercises or meditation
    3. 10 minutes before â€” short gratitude journaling

Small habits work wonders: my mood improved, my attention became more stable, and the days became more fulfilling but not exhausting.

ğŸ“š Study: How to Study Smarter, Not Longer

Hereâ€™s my study formula:

graph LR A[Reading] --> B[Note-taking] B --> C[Rephrasing out loud] C --> D[Self-testing] D --> E[Review after 1 day] E --> F[Review after 1 week]

ğŸ” Comments on Techniques

  • Feynman Technique â€” helps identify weak spots in understanding. If you canâ€™t explain it simply, you havenâ€™t understood it.
  • Spaced Repetition â€” based on Ebbinghausâ€™s forgetting curve. You review right before forgetting it â€” and remember it for much longer.
  • Pomodoro â€” protects against burnout. After 4 “Pomodoros,” you can tackle a tough topic.
  • Mind Maps â€” perfect for logic and associations. Especially useful for theory.

ğŸŒ³ Beautiful and Hidden Parks in Moscow

These parks won’t have crowds of tourists, but theyâ€™ll offer plenty of space, trees, and silence.

ğŸŒ² Lianozovsky Park

  • Location: North Moscow
  • Features: Forest atmosphere, wide paths, few people
  • Tip: Perfect for a morning coffee and reading under the trees

ğŸŒ³ Kuskovo Forest Park

  • Location: East Moscow, Veshnyaki district
  • Features: Estate, old pond, real forest
  • Tip: Great for walking while listening to podcasts or recording voice notes

ğŸŒ¿ Timiryazevsky Forest

  • Location: Near the “Timiryazevskaya” platform
  • Features: Wild trails, squirrels, pine scent
  • Tip: Great for solitude, you can even study there

ğŸƒ Bitsevsky Forest

  • Location: South Moscow
  • Features: Really feels like a forest, not a park. Paths, ravines, streams
  • Tip: If you’re tired of everything â€” just walk along the path and breathe

ğŸ’¬ Conclusion

The week was busy, but balanced: study, activity, walks, a bit of rest â€” everything in its place. I realized that the most important thing is not the amount of things you do, but how you feel during the process.

Stay active but take care of yourself ğŸ’š

item.title: ğŸŒ¿ A Week Outdoors, Studying, and the Concert of My Dreams ğŸ¶
item.description:
Lately, I’ve been spending as much time outdoors as possibleâ€”walking, exploring parks, and riding the Moscow Central Circle. These trips are incredibly relaxing and a great way to escape the hustle and bustle.

Of course, studying never stops: working on computer architecture labs, diving into programming fundamentals, and tackling mathematical analysis and logicâ€”my brain is definitely getting a workout! ğŸ“š

ğŸ“– The Benefits of a Balanced Study Load

One great thing about my studies is that the workload is not overwhelming. This allows me to fully grasp the material, which is presented in a clear and engaging way. There’s also plenty of time for self-developmentâ€”whether it’s learning additional skills, exploring new interests, or looking for part-time job opportunities. This balance makes studying much more enjoyable and effective.

But the highlight of the week was the Oleg LSP concert! ğŸ¤ğŸ”¥ Favorite songs, an amazing atmosphere, and tons of emotionsâ€”Iâ€™m fully recharged and ready for new challenges.

ğŸ”¥ How to Stay Energized?

I try to maintain a healthy lifestyle, and it really helps me feel better.

âœ” Sleep is a Superpower ğŸ˜´

No matter how much you have to do, sleep should be a priority. Chronic sleep deprivation lowers concentration, increases irritability, and weakens the immune system. 7-9 hours of sleep is key to a productive day and a good mood.

âœ” Nutritionâ€”Fuel for the Brain ğŸğŸ¥‘

Simple rule: balanced nutrition = more energy.
ğŸ”¹ Proteins (meat, fish, legumes) help with recovery and strength.
ğŸ”¹ Slow carbs (whole grains, vegetables) provide lasting energy without sugar crashes.
ğŸ”¹ Healthy fats (avocado, nuts, olive oil) support brain function.
âŒ Too much fast food and sweetsâ€”a quick energy boost, followed by a crash and fatigue. Moderation is key!

âœ” Movement + Fresh Air ğŸš¶â€â™€ï¸

Walking isn’t just about enjoying the sceneryâ€”itâ€™s also great for your health. Physical activity boosts mood and improves concentration.

â“ How do you take care of your well-being? Share your healthy habits! ğŸ˜Š
